newsitem.title: CANADA: Shell Canada proposed bitumen pipeline.
newsitem.headline: Shell Canada proposed bitumen pipeline.

text.p: Shell Canada Ltd said on Thursday it proposed a C$375 million pipeline to ship bitumen to Edmonton, Alberta from its planned C$1 billion oil sands project in the northeastern part of the Canadian province.

Shell Canada, which announced in March a proposal to develop its Lease 13 north of Fort McMurray, said the pipeline would ship about 200,000 barrels of bitumen a day 500 km to its Scotford refinery and other markets.
Bitumen is the thick, heavy crude in oil sands.
The Corridor Pipeline would also ship about 60,000 barrels of diluent north to Lease 13 to blend with the bitumen and allow it to flow in the pipeline.

Lease 13 would produce between 120,000 and 150,000 barrels a day of bitumen starting in 2002. If Shell Canada and regulators gave the project the green light, it would be Canada's second-largest oil sands project.
The company has said it was assessing options for upgrading the bitumen into synthetic crude oil, including building a new upgrader at the Scotford plant.

"The Edmonton area is the natural destination for the bitumen produced from Lease 13 -- since the Scotford Refinery is the key to our marketing strategy," Shell Canada vice-president Neil Camarta said in a statement.
The Corridor Pipeline is the latest in a spate of pipelines proposed for shipping growing heavy oil and oil sands production from northeastern Alberta.
Other lines have recently been proposed by Suncor Energy Inc and IPL Energy Inc, Alberta Energy Co Ltd and Husky Oil Ltd as well as Imperial Oil Ltd.
Shell Canada said it planned to make a formal regulatory filing for its project in the spring of 1998. ((Reuters Calgary Bureau (403) 531-1624))
